Hi,

Ian Badcoe wrote:

>I think the initial goal is just to model one neocortical column, about 
>50,000 neurones I think they said.
>  
>
Yes I think the media may have overstated the project's parameters just 
a little, as Ken suggested. A comment on slashdot pointed out that this 
type of research isn't new per se, that the main point to register is 
the computer IBM are/will be building to run the simulations and that 
the overblown reporting mainly exists to push IBM's share price up.

>There's a popular folk-lore that neocortical columns have somehting to do 
>with general intelligence.
>
>There are about a million of them in the human brain, all roughly repeats 
>of the same "module"...
>  
>
Maybe something to mull over for the folks considering a developmental 
genome encoding. I wonder if there is anything particularly useful to be 
gained from arranging neurons in columns as opposed to some other 
shape/arrangment? I suppose it gives some basic level of organisation to 
work up from, in that respect maybe the use of columns is an 
evolutionary accident - which is to say that perhaps some ancestor of 
ours 'evolved' columns, and they worked as well as any other arrangement 
and therefore evolution hasn't 'bothered' to explore other arrangments - 
a local maxima of sorts. maybe.

>However, they are being (written up as) very ambitious and might crash and 
>burn.  e.g in an experiment like this, OK you can copy the topology but 
>then you need to choose a model neurone behaviour.  If the whole does not 
>behave, you cannot extrapolate back to what the error in the neurone 
>equations was...
>  
>
I think they have been experimenting with biological neurons in the lab. 
I would guess that initially they'll be tweaking the parameters and 
observing what behaviour results. Nothing more. I wonder what a single 
column can achieve? I suppose very roughly you could extrapolate up from 
ANN experiments, or down from mouse brains. Most insects I think have 
something in the range of 50k neurons, but their arrangement and use is 
likely to be very different from a typical 50k column in a mammalian 
brain. Which makes me wonder how much of an insect's brain circuitry is 
encoded in DNA, since they are mainly(entirely?) creatures operating on 
instinct.

Colin.
